the interpreted system model offers a computationally grounded model , in terms of the states of computer processes , to s5 epistemic logics . <edu_end> this paper extends the interpreted system model , <edu_end> and provides a computationally grounded one , <edu_end> called the interpreted perception system model , to those epis - temic logics other than s5 . <edu_end> it is usually assumed , in the interpreted system model , <edu_end> that those parts of the environment <edu_end> that are visible to an agent <edu_end> are correctly perceived by the agent as a whole . <edu_end> the essential idea of the interpreted perception system model is that an agent may have incorrect perception or observations to the visible parts of the environment <edu_end> and the agent may not be aware of this . <edu_end> the notion of knowledge can be defined <edu_end> so that an agent knows a statement iff <edu_end> the statement holds in those states <edu_end> that the agent can not distinguish -lrb- from the current state -rrb- <edu_end> by using only her correct observations . <edu_end> we establish a logic of knowledge and certainty , <edu_end> called kc logic , with a sound and complete proof system . <edu_end> the knowledge modality in this computationally grounded model is s4 valid . <edu_end> it becomes s5 <edu_end> if we assume <edu_end> an agent always has correct observations ; <edu_end> and more interestingly , it can be s4 .2 or s4 .3 under other natural constraints on agents and their sensors to the environment . <edu_end>

projector - camera systems use computer vision <edu_end> to analyze their surroundings <edu_end> and display feedback directly onto real world objects , <edu_end> as embodied by spatial augmented reality . <edu_end> to be effective , <edu_end> the display must remain aligned <edu_end> even when the target object moves , <edu_end> but the added illumination causes problems for traditional algorithms . <edu_end> current solutions consider the displayed content as interference <edu_end> and largely depend on channels orthogonal to visible light . <edu_end> they can not directly align projector images with real world surfaces , <edu_end> even though this may be the actual goal . <edu_end> we propose instead to model the light <edu_end> emitted by projectors <edu_end> and reflected into cameras , <edu_end> and to consider the displayed content as additional information useful for direct alignment . <edu_end> we implemented in software an algorithm <edu_end> that successfully executes on planar surfaces of diffuse reflectance properties at almost two frames per second with subpixel accuracy . <edu_end> although slow , our work proves the viability of the concept , <edu_end> paving the way for future optimization and generalization . <edu_end>

deduction , induction , and analogy pervade all our thinking . <edu_end> in contrast with deduction , <edu_end> understanding logical aspects of induction and analogy is still an important and challenging issue of artificial intelligence . <edu_end> this paper describes a logical formalization , <edu_end> called production , of common conjectural reasoning of both induction and analogy . <edu_end> by introduction of preduction , <edu_end> logical formalization is refined into ` ` preduction + deduction '' and -lrb- empirical -rrb- inductive reasoning is refined into ` ` preduction + mathematical induction '' . <edu_end> we examine generality of preduction through applications to various examples on induction and analogy . <edu_end>

the geometric median is a classic robust estimator of centrality for data in euclidean spaces . <edu_end> in this paper we formulate the geometric median of data on a riemannian manifold as the minimizer of the sum of geodesic distances to the data points . <edu_end> we prove existence and uniqueness of the geometric median on manifolds with non - positive sectional curvature <edu_end> and give sufficient conditions for uniqueness on positively curved manifolds . <edu_end> generalizing the weiszfeld procedure <edu_end> for finding the geometric median of euclidean data , <edu_end> we present an algorithm <edu_end> for computing the geometric median on an arbitrary manifold . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that this algorithm converges to the unique solution <edu_end> when it exists . <edu_end> this method produces a robust central point for data <edu_end> lying on a manifold , <edu_end> and should have use in a variety of vision applications <edu_end> involving manifolds . <edu_end> we give examples of the geometric median computation and demonstrate its robustness for three types of manifold data : <edu_end> the 3d rotation group , tensor manifolds , and shape spaces . <edu_end>

numerous recent approaches attempt <edu_end> to remove image blur due to camera shake , either with one or multiple input images , <edu_end> by explicitly solving an inverse and inherently ill - posed deconvolution problem . <edu_end> if the photographer takes a burst of images , <edu_end> a modality available in virtually all modern digital cameras , <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that it is possible to combine them <edu_end> to get a clean sharp version . <edu_end> this is done <edu_end> without explicitly solving any blur estimation and subsequent inverse problem . <edu_end> the proposed algorithm is strikingly simple : <edu_end> it performs a weighted average in the fourier domain , with weights <edu_end> depending on the fourier spectrum magnitude . <edu_end> the method 's rationale is that camera shake has a random nature <edu_end> and therefore each image in the burst is generally blurred differently . <edu_end> experiments with real camera data show <edu_end> that the proposed fourier burst accumulation algorithm achieves state - of - the - art results an order of magnitude faster , with simplicity for on - board implementation on camera phones . <edu_end>

the formulation of trace quotient is shared by many computer vision problems ; <edu_end> however , it was conventionally approximated by an essentially different formulation of quotient trace , <edu_end> which can be solved with the generalized eigenvalue decomposition approach . <edu_end> in this paper , we present a direct solution to the former formulation . <edu_end> first , considering that the feasible solutions are constrained on a grassmann manifold , <edu_end> we present a necessary condition for the optimal solution of the trace quotient problem , <edu_end> which then naturally elicits an iterative procedure <edu_end> for pursuing the optimal solution . <edu_end> the proposed algorithm , <edu_end> referred to as optimal projection pursuing , <edu_end> has the following characteristics : <edu_end> 1 -rrb- optimal projection <edu_end> pursuing directly optimizes the trace quotient , <edu_end> and is theoretically optimal ; <edu_end> 2 -rrb- optimal projection <edu_end> pursuing does not suffer from the solution uncertainty issue <edu_end> existing in the quotient trace formulation <edu_end> that the objective function value is invariant under any non - singular linear transformation , <edu_end> and optimal projection <edu_end> pursuing is invariant only under orthogonal transformations , <edu_end> which does not affect final distance measurement ; <edu_end> and 3 -rrb- optimal projection pursuing reveals the underlying equivalence between the trace quotient problem and the corresponding trace difference problem . <edu_end> extensive experiments on face recognition validate the superiority of optimal projection <edu_end> pursuing over the solution of the corresponding quotient trace problem in both objective function value and classification capability . <edu_end>

active learning refers to algorithmic frameworks <edu_end> aimed at selecting training data points <edu_end> in order to reduce the number of required training data points <edu_end> and/or improve the generalization performance of a learning method . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we present an asymptotic analysis of active learning for generalized linear models . <edu_end> our analysis holds under the common practical situation of model misspecifica - tion , <edu_end> and is based on realistic assumptions <edu_end> regarding the nature of the sampling distributions , <edu_end> which are usually neither independent nor identical . <edu_end> we derive un - biased estimators of generalization performance , as well as estimators of expected reduction in generalization error <edu_end> after adding a new training data point , <edu_end> that allow us to optimize its sampling distributions through a convex optimization problem . <edu_end> our analysis naturally leads to an algorithm for sequential active learning <edu_end> which is applicable for all tasks <edu_end> supported by generalized linear models -lrb- e.g. , binary classification , multi - class classification , regression -rrb- and can be applied in non - linear settings through the use of mercer kernels . <edu_end>

most previous visual recognition systems simply assume ideal inputs <edu_end> without real - world degradations , such as low resolution , motion blur and out - of - focus blur . <edu_end> in presence of such unknown degradations , <edu_end> the conventional approach first resorts to blind image restoration <edu_end> and then feeds the restored image into a classifier . <edu_end> treating restoration and recognition separately , <edu_end> such a straightforward approach , however , suffers greatly from the defective output of the ill - posed blind image restoration . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we present a joint blind image restoration and recognition method <edu_end> based on the sparse representation <edu_end> prior to handle the challenging problem of face recognition from low - quality images , <edu_end> where the degradation model is realistic <edu_end> and totally unknown . <edu_end> the sparse representation prior states <edu_end> that the degraded input image , <edu_end> if correctly restored , <edu_end> will have a good sparse representation in terms of the training set , <edu_end> which indicates the identity of the test image . <edu_end> the proposed joint blind image restoration and recognition method achieves simultaneous restoration and recognition <edu_end> by iteratively solving the blind image restoration in pursuit of the sparest representation for face recognition . <edu_end> based on such a sparse representation prior , <edu_end> we demonstrate <edu_end> that the image restoration task and the recognition task can benefit greatly from each other . <edu_end> extensive experiments on face datasets under various degradations are carried out <edu_end> and the results of our joint blind image restoration and recognition method shows significant improvements over conventional methods <edu_end> of treating the two tasks independently . <edu_end>

in this paper we present a new method for pitch estimation <edu_end> using a system <edu_end> based on phase - locked - loop devices . <edu_end> three main blocks define our system . <edu_end> the aim of the first one is to make an harmonic decomposition of the speech signal . <edu_end> this stage is implemented <edu_end> using a band - pass filter bank and phase - locked - loops cascaded to the output of each filter . <edu_end> a second block enhances the harmonic <edu_end> corresponding to the fundamental frequency <edu_end> and attenuates all other harmonics . <edu_end> finally a third stage re - synthesizes a new signal with high energy at the fundamental frequency <edu_end> and extracts pitch contour from that signal <edu_end> using another phase locked - loop . <edu_end> performance is evaluated over two databases of laryngograph - labeled speech and <edu_end> compared to various well known pitch estimation algorithms . <edu_end>

image denoising is an under - determined problem , <edu_end> and hence it is important to define appropriate image priors for regularization . <edu_end> one recent popular prior is the graph laplacian regularizer , <edu_end> where a given pixel patch is assumed to be smooth in the graph - signal domain . <edu_end> the strength and direction of the resulting image priors are computed from the graph 's edge weights . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we derive the optimal edge weights for local graph - based filtering <edu_end> using gradient estimates from non - local pixel patches <edu_end> that are self - similar . <edu_end> to analyze the effects of the gradient estimates on the graph laplacian reg - ularizer , <edu_end> we first show theoretically <edu_end> that , <edu_end> given graph - signal h d is a set of discrete samples on continuous function h -lrb- x , y -rrb- in a closed region ω , graph laplacian regularizer -lrb- h d -rrb- t lh d converges to a continuous functional sω <edu_end> integrating gradient norm of h in metric space g <edu_end> -- i.e. , -lrb- ∇ h -rrb- t g − 1 -lrb- ∇ h -rrb- -- over ω . <edu_end> we then derive the optimal metric space g : <edu_end> one that leads to a graph laplacian regu - larizer <edu_end> that is discriminant <edu_end> when the gradient estimates are accurate , <edu_end> and robust <edu_end> when the gradient estimates are noisy . <edu_end> finally , having derived g <edu_end> we compute the corresponding edge weights <edu_end> to define the laplacian l <edu_end> used for filtering . <edu_end> experimental results show <edu_end> that our image denoising algorithm <edu_end> using the per - patch optimal metric space g outperforms non - local means by up to 1.5 db in non - local means . <edu_end>

in recent years , planning and scheduling research has paid increasing attention to problems <edu_end> that involve resource over - subscription , <edu_end> where cumulative demand for resources out - strips their availability <edu_end> and some subset of goals or tasks must be excluded . <edu_end> two basic classes of techniques <edu_end> to solve oversubscribed scheduling problems <edu_end> have emerged : <edu_end> searching directly in the space of possible schedules <edu_end> and searching in an alternative space of task permutations <edu_end> -lrb- by relying on a schedule builder <edu_end> to provide a mapping <edu_end> to schedule space -rrb- . in some problem contexts , permutation - based search methods have been shown to outperform schedule - space search methods , <edu_end> while in others the opposite has been shown to be the case . <edu_end> we consider two techniques <edu_end> for which this behavior has been observed : <edu_end> taskswap , a schedule - space repair search procedure , and squeaky wheel optimization , a permutation - space scheduling procedure . <edu_end> we analyze the circumstances <edu_end> under which one can be expected to dominate the other . <edu_end> starting from a real - world scheduling problem <edu_end> where squeaky wheel optimization has been shown to outperform taskswap , <edu_end> we construct a series of problem instances <edu_end> that increasingly incorporate characteristics of a second real - world scheduling problem , <edu_end> where taskswap has been found to outperform squeaky wheel optimization . <edu_end> experimental results provide insights <edu_end> into when schedule - space methods and permutation - based methods may be most appropriate . <edu_end>

this paper proposes and evaluates a new spectral smoothing technique <edu_end> whose performance is comparable with lsp interpolation in terms of euclidean spectral distance measurements <edu_end> but whose interpolated formant trajectories are more reasonable from a phonetic point of view . <edu_end> the spectral smoothing technique firstly estimates derivative logarithmic magnitude spectra from both the source and the target frame <edu_end> represented by autoregressive filter coefficients . <edu_end> then , dynamic programming yields the best alignment between these two spectral representations . <edu_end> smoothed frequency responses are achieved by weighted linear interpolation between the corresponding source and target spectral lines <edu_end> whose alignment was found by dp backtracking . <edu_end> finally , the spectrum is converted to autoregressive filter coefficients with the intermediate stage of autocorrelation coefficients . <edu_end>

articulated objects represent an important class of objects in our everyday environment . <edu_end> automatic detection of the type of articulated or otherwise restricted motion and extraction of the corresponding motion parameters are therefore of high value , <edu_end> e.g. in order to augment an otherwise static 3d reconstruction with dynamic semantics , such as rotation axes and allowable translation directions for certain rigid parts or objects . <edu_end> hence , in this paper , a novel theory <edu_end> to analyse relative transformations between two motion - restricted parts will be presented . <edu_end> the analysis is based on linear subspaces <edu_end> spanned by relative transformations . <edu_end> moreover , a signature for relative transformations will be introduced <edu_end> which uniquely specifies the type of restricted motion <edu_end> encoded in these relative transformations . <edu_end> this theoretic framework enables the derivation of novel algebraic constraints , such as low - rank constraints for subsequent rotations around two fixed axes for example . <edu_end> lastly , given the type of restricted motion <edu_end> as predicted by the signature , <edu_end> the paper shows <edu_end> how to extract all the motion parameters with matrix manipulations from linear algebra . <edu_end> our theory is verified on several real data sets , such as a rotating blackboard or a wheel rolling on the floor amongst others . <edu_end>

we develop an intuitive geometric interpretation of the standard support vector machine for classification of both linearly separable and inseparable data <edu_end> and provide a rigorous derivation of the concepts behind the geometry . <edu_end> for the separable case finding the maximum margin between the two sets is equivalent to finding the closest points in the smallest convex sets <edu_end> that contain each class -lrb- the convex hulls -rrb- . <edu_end> we now extend this argument to the inseparable case <edu_end> by using a reduced convex hull formulation <edu_end> reduced away from out - liers . <edu_end> we prove <edu_end> that solving the reduced convex hull formulation is exactly equivalent to solving the standard inseparable svm for appropriate choices of parameters . <edu_end> some additional advantages of the new formulation are that the effect of the choice of parameters becomes geometrically clear <edu_end> and that the formulation may be solved by fast nearest point algorithms . <edu_end> by changing norms <edu_end> these arguments hold for both the standard 2-norm and 1-norm svm . <edu_end>

correlation filters take advantage of specific properties in the fourier domain <edu_end> allowing them to be estimated efficiently : <edu_end> o -lrb- n d log d -rrb- in the frequency domain , versus o -lrb- d 3 + n d 2 -rrb- spatially where d is signal length , <edu_end> and n is the number of signals . <edu_end> recent extensions to correlation filters , such as mosse , have reignited interest of their use in the vision community due to their robustness and attractive computational properties . <edu_end> in this paper we demonstrate , however , <edu_end> that this computational efficiency comes at a cost . <edu_end> specifically , we demonstrate <edu_end> that only 1 d proportion of shifted examples are unaffected by boundary effects <edu_end> which has a dramatic effect on detection / tracking performance . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we propose a novel approach to correlation filter estimation <edu_end> that : <edu_end> -lrb- i -rrb- takes advantage of inherent computational redundancies in the frequency domain , -lrb- ii -rrb- dramatically reduces boundary effects , <edu_end> and -lrb- iii -rrb- is able to implicitly exploit all possible patches <edu_end> densely extracted from training examples during learning process . <edu_end> impressive object tracking and detection results are presented in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency . <edu_end>
sampling repeated clinical laboratory tests with appropriate timing is challenging <edu_end> because the latent physio - logic function being sampled <edu_end> is in general nonstation - ary . <edu_end> when ordering repeated tests , <edu_end> clinicians adopt various simple strategies <edu_end> that may or may not be well suited to the behavior of the function . <edu_end> previous research on this topic has been primarily focused on cost - driven assessments of oversampling . <edu_end> but for monitoring physiologic state or for retrospective analysis , <edu_end> undersampling can be much more problematic than oversampling . <edu_end> in this paper we analyze hundreds of observation sequences of four different clinical laboratory tests <edu_end> to provide princi - pled , data - driven estimates of undersampling and over - sampling , <edu_end> and to assess whether the sampling adapts to changing volatility of the latent function . <edu_end> to do this , <edu_end> we developed a new method <edu_end> for fitting a gaussian process to samples of a nonstationary latent function . <edu_end> our method includes an explicit estimate of the latent func - tion 's volatility over time , <edu_end> which is deterministically related to its nonstationarity . <edu_end> we find on average that the degree of undersampling is up to an order of magnitude greater than oversampling , <edu_end> and that only a small minority are sampled with an adaptive strategy . <edu_end>
the accurate estimation of covariance matrices is essential for many signal processing and machine learning algorithms . <edu_end> in high dimensional settings the sample covariance is known to perform poorly , <edu_end> hence regularization strategies such as analytic shrinkage of ledoit / wolf are applied . <edu_end> in the standard setting , <edu_end> i.i.d . <edu_end> data is assumed , <edu_end> however , in practice , time series typically exhibit strong autocorrela - tion structure , <edu_end> which introduces a pronounced estimation bias . <edu_end> recent work by sancetta has extended the shrinkage framework beyond i.i.d . data . <edu_end> we contribute in this work <edu_end> by showing <edu_end> that the sancetta estimator , <edu_end> while being consistent in the high - dimensional limit , <edu_end> suffers from a high bias in finite sample sizes . <edu_end> we propose an alternative estimator , <edu_end> which is -lrb- 1 -rrb- unbiased , -lrb- 2 -rrb- less sensitive to hyperparame - ter choice and -lrb- 3 -rrb- yields superior performance in simulations on toy data and on a real world data set from an eeg - based brain - computer - interfacing experiment . <edu_end>

many existing explanation methods in bayesian networks , such as maximum a posteriori assignment and most probable explanation , generate complete assignments for target variables . <edu_end> a pri - ori , the set of target variables is often large , <edu_end> but only a few of them may be most relevant <edu_end> in explaining given evidence . <edu_end> generating explanations with all the target variables <edu_end> is hence not always desirable . <edu_end> this paper addresses the problem <edu_end> by proposing a new framework <edu_end> called most relevant explanation , <edu_end> which aims to automatically identify the most relevant target variables . <edu_end> we will also discuss in detail a specific instance of the framework <edu_end> that uses generalized bayes factor as the relevance measure . <edu_end> finally we will propose an approximate algorithm <edu_end> based on reversible jump mcmc and simulated annealing <edu_end> to solve most relevant explanation . <edu_end> empirical results show <edu_end> that the new approximate algorithm typically finds much more concise explanations than existing methods . <edu_end>

we argue <edu_end> that parameterized complexity is a useful tool <edu_end> with which to study global constraints . <edu_end> in particular , we show <edu_end> that many global constraints <edu_end> which are intractable <edu_end> to propagate completely <edu_end> have natural parameters <edu_end> which make them fixed - parameter tractable <edu_end> and which are easy to compute . <edu_end> this tractability tends either to be the result of a simple dynamic program or of a decomposition <edu_end> which has a strong backdoor of bounded size . <edu_end> this strong backdoor is often a cycle cutset . <edu_end> we also show <edu_end> that parameterized complexity can be used <edu_end> to study other aspects of constraint programming like symmetry breaking . <edu_end> for instance , we prove <edu_end> that value symmetry is fixed - parameter tractable to break in the number of symmetries . <edu_end> finally , we argue <edu_end> that parameterized complexity can be used <edu_end> to derive results about the approximability of constraint propagation . <edu_end>

<edu_end> when an autoregressive process is observed through a sparse multipath environment , <edu_end> its ar parameters may be estimated <edu_end> by searching for a symmetric finite impulse response filter , <edu_end> which , <edu_end> when convolved with the observed signal 's autocorrelation sequence , <edu_end> yields the sparsest output . <edu_end> the zeros of that filter would then correspond to the poles of the ar process . <edu_end> when the 0-norm of the output is used as a measure of its sparsity , <edu_end> consistency of the resulting estimate -lrb- under some simple conditions -rrb- is readily obtained . <edu_end> however , due to problematic aspects of 0-norm minimization , <edu_end> it is often more convenient to resort to 1-norm minimization . <edu_end> a question of major interest in this context is whether -lrb- and if so , under what conditions -rrb- consistency of the resulting estimate is maintained . <edu_end> by analyzing the perturbations of the 1-norm about the desired solution , <edu_end> we derive -lrb- and illustrate -rrb- specific conditions for consistency . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that <edu_end> when the multipath reflections are sufficiently sparse , <edu_end> consistency is guaranteed for a very wide range of ar parameters and reflection gains . <edu_end>

this paper proposes a novel approach <edu_end> for estimating the spectral envelope of voiced speech independently of its harmonic structure . <edu_end> because of the quasi - periodicity of voiced speech , <edu_end> its spectrum indicates harmonic structure <edu_end> and only has energy at frequencies <edu_end> corresponding to integral multiples of 1/4 . <edu_end> it is hence impossible to identify transfer characteristics between the adjacent harmonics . <edu_end> in order to resolve this problem , <edu_end> multi - frame analysis is introduced . <edu_end> the mfa estimates a spectral envelope <edu_end> using many portions of speech <edu_end> which are vo - calised <edu_end> using the same vocal - tract shape . <edu_end> since each of the portions usually has a different 1/4 and ensuing different harmonic structure , <edu_end> a number of harmonics can be obtained at various frequencies <edu_end> to form a spectral envelope . <edu_end> the method thereby gives a closer approximation to the vocal - tract transfer function . <edu_end>

the standard approach to the classification of objects is to consider the examples as independent and identically distributed -lrb- iid -rrb- . in many real world settings , <edu_end> however , <edu_end> this assumption is not valid , <edu_end> because a topo - graphical relationship exists between the objects . <edu_end> in this contribution <edu_end> we consider the special case of image segmentation , <edu_end> where the objects are pixels <edu_end> and where the underlying topography is a 2d regular rectangular grid . <edu_end> we introduce a classification method <edu_end> which not only uses measured vectorial feature information but also the label configuration within a to - pographic neighborhood . <edu_end> due to the resulting dependence between the labels of neighboring pixels , <edu_end> a collective classification of a set of pixels becomes necessary . <edu_end> we propose a new method <edu_end> called ` topographic support vector machine ' -lrb- tsvm -rrb- , <edu_end> which is based on a topographic kernel and a self - consistent solution to the label assignment <edu_end> shown to be equivalent to a recurrent neural network . <edu_end> the performance of the algorithm is compared to a conventional svm on a cell image segmentation task . <edu_end>

<edu_end> despite recent breakthroughs in the applications of deep neural networks , <edu_end> one setting <edu_end> that presents a persistent challenge <edu_end> is that of '' one - shot learning . <edu_end> '' traditional gradient - based networks require a lot of data <edu_end> to learn , often through extensive iterative training . <edu_end> when new data is encountered , <edu_end> the models must inefficiently relearn their parameters <edu_end> to adequately incorporate the new information <edu_end> without catastrophic interference . <edu_end> architec - tures with augmented memory capacities , such as neural turing machines , offer the ability <edu_end> to quickly encode and retrieve new information , <edu_end> and hence can potentially obviate the down - sides of conventional models . <edu_end> here , we demonstrate the ability of a memory - augmented neu - ral network <edu_end> to rapidly assimilate new data , <edu_end> and leverage this data <edu_end> to make accurate predictions after only a few samples . <edu_end> we also introduce a new method <edu_end> for accessing an external memory <edu_end> that focuses on memory content , <edu_end> unlike previous methods <edu_end> that additionally use memory location - based focusing mechanisms . <edu_end>
we propose a content - based approach to mine parallel resources from the entire web <edu_end> using cross lingual information retrieval with search query relevance score . <edu_end> our content - based approach improves mining recall <edu_end> by going beyond url <edu_end> matching to find parallel documents from non - parallel sites . <edu_end> we introduce search query relevance score <edu_end> to improve the precision of mining . <edu_end> our content - based approach makes use of search engines <edu_end> to query for target document <edu_end> given each source document <edu_end> and therefore does not require downloading target language documents in batch mode , <edu_end> reducing computational cost on the local machines and bandwidth consumption . <edu_end> we obtained a very high mining precision -lrb- 88 % -rrb- on the parallel documents by the pure clir approach . <edu_end> after extracting parallel sentences from the mined documents <edu_end> and using them <edu_end> to train an cross lingual information retrieval , <edu_end> we found <edu_end> that the smt performance , with 29.88 bleu score , is comparable to that <edu_end> obtained with high quality manually translated parallel sentences with 29.54 bleu score , <edu_end> illustrating the excellent quality of the mined parallel material . <edu_end>
a time domain simulation of acoustic propagation in the vocal tract requires the spatial and temporal discretization of the equations of motion and continuity . <edu_end> in the classic transmission line model of the vocal tract with lumped elements , <edu_end> the spatial discretization is provided by the piece - wise constant area function . <edu_end> the temporal finite - difference approximation of the differential equations can , however , vary from one implementation to the other -lrb- e.g. , -lsb- 4 -rsb- vs. -lsb- 5 -rsb- -rrb- . in this study , <edu_end> we have adopted a general finite - difference scheme <edu_end> that depends on a parameter θ <edu_end> where 0 ≤ θ ≤ 1 . <edu_end> as special cases , this general finite - difference scheme includes the trapezoid rule -lrb- θ = 0.5 -rrb- as well as the implicit -lrb- θ = 1 -rrb- and explicit -lrb- θ = 0 -rrb- finite - difference schemes . <edu_end> we have examined <edu_end> how formant frequencies and bandwidths of simulated vowels are effected by the choice of θ . <edu_end> the experiments were conducted for the sampling rates of 44.1 khz and 88.2 khz <edu_end> and compared with the accurate and thus desirable frequencies and bandwidths <edu_end> measured in frequency domain simulations of the vocal tract . <edu_end> it can be shown <edu_end> that optimal values for θ are slightly above 0.5 <edu_end> depending on the sampling rate . <edu_end>
non - negative matrix factorization -lrb- non - negative matrix factorization -rrb- has previously been shown to be a useful decomposition for multivariate data . <edu_end> two different multi - plicative algorithms for non - negative matrix factorization are analyzed . <edu_end> non - negative matrix factorization differ only slightly in the multiplicative factor <edu_end> used in the update rules . <edu_end> one algorithm can be shown <edu_end> to minimize the conventional least squares error <edu_end> while the other minimizes the generalized kullback - leibler divergence . <edu_end> the monotonic convergence of both algorithms can be proven <edu_end> using an auxiliary function <edu_end> analogous to that <edu_end> used for proving convergence of the expectation - maximization algorithm . <edu_end> the algorithms can also be interpreted as diagonally rescaled gradient descent , <edu_end> where the rescaling factor is optimally chosen <edu_end> to ensure convergence . <edu_end>
this paper aims at a newly raising task in visual surveillance : <edu_end> re - identifying people at a distance <edu_end> by matching body information , <edu_end> given several reference examples . <edu_end> most of existing works solve this task <edu_end> by matching a reference template with the target individual , <edu_end> but often suffer from large human appearance variability -lrb- e.g. different poses / views , illumination -rrb- and high false positives <edu_end> in matching caused by conjunctions , occlusions or surrounding clutters . <edu_end> addressing these problems , <edu_end> we construct a simple yet expressive template from a few reference images of a certain individual , <edu_end> which represents the body as an articulated assembly of compositional and alternative parts , <edu_end> and propose an effective matching algorithm with cluster sampling . <edu_end> this algorithm is designed within a candidacy graph <edu_end> whose vertices are matching candidates -lrb- i.e. a pair of source and target body parts -rrb- , <edu_end> and iterates in two steps for convergence . <edu_end> -lrb- i -rrb- it generates possible partial matches <edu_end> based on compatible and competitive relations among body parts . <edu_end> -lrb- ii -rrb- it confirms the partial matches <edu_end> to generate a new matching solution , <edu_end> which is accepted by the markov chain monte carlo mechanism . <edu_end> in the experiments , <edu_end> we demonstrate the superior performance of our approach on three public databases <edu_end> compared to existing methods . <edu_end>
many ai problems , <edu_end> when formalized , <edu_end> reduce to evaluating the probability <edu_end> that a propo - sitional expression is true . <edu_end> in this paper we show <edu_end> that this problem is computationally intractable <edu_end> even in surprisingly restricted cases <edu_end> and even if we settle for an approximation to this probability . <edu_end> we consider various methods <edu_end> used in approximate reasoning such as computing degree of belief and bayesian belief networks , as well as reasoning techniques such as constraint satisfaction and knowledge compilation , <edu_end> that use approximation <edu_end> to avoid computational diiculties , <edu_end> and reduce them to model - counting problems over a propositional domain . <edu_end> we prove <edu_end> that counting satisfying assignments of propositional languages is intractable even for horn and monotone formulae , <edu_end> and even when the size of clauses and number of occurrences of the variables are extremely limited . <edu_end> this should be contrasted with the case of deductive reasoning , <edu_end> where horn theories and theories with binary clauses are distinguished by the existence of linear time satissability algorithms . <edu_end> what is even more surprising is that , <edu_end> as we show , <edu_end> even approximating the number of satisfying assignments -lrb- i.e. , \ approximating '' approximate reasoning -rrb- , is intractable for most of these restricted theories . <edu_end> we also identify some restricted classes of propositional formulae <edu_end> for which eecient algorithms for counting satisfying assignments can be given . <edu_end>
we propose a novel attentional model for simultaneous object tracking and recognition <edu_end> that is driven by gaze data . <edu_end> motivated by theories of the human perceptual system , <edu_end> the attentional model consists of two interacting pathways : <edu_end> ventral and dorsal . <edu_end> the ventral pathway models object appearance and classification <edu_end> using deep -lrb- factored -rrb- - restricted boltzmann machines . <edu_end> at each point in time , <edu_end> the observations consist of retinal images , with decaying resolution toward the periphery of the gaze . <edu_end> the dorsal pathway models the location , orientation , scale and speed of the attended object . <edu_end> the posterior distribution of these states is estimated with particle filtering . <edu_end> deeper in the dorsal pathway , <edu_end> we encounter an attentional mechanism <edu_end> that learns to control gazes <edu_end> so as to minimize tracking uncertainty . <edu_end> the attentional model is modular -lrb- with each module easily replaceable with more sophisticated algorithms -rrb- , straightforward to implement , practically efficient , <edu_end> and works well in simple video sequences . <edu_end>

translucent objects pose a difficult problem for traditional structured light 3d scanning techniques . <edu_end> subsurface scattering corrupts the range estimation in two ways : <edu_end> by drastically reducing the signal - to - noise ratio <edu_end> and by shifting the intensity peak beneath the surface to a point <edu_end> which does not coincide with the point of incidence . <edu_end> in this paper we analyze and compare two descattering methods <edu_end> in order to obtain reliable 3d coordinates for translucent objects . <edu_end> by using polarization - difference imaging , <edu_end> subsurface scattering can be filtered out <edu_end> because multiple scattering ran - domizes the polarization direction of light <edu_end> while the surface reflectance partially keeps the polarization direction of the illumination . <edu_end> the descattered reflectance can be used for reliable 3d coordinates <edu_end> using traditional optical 3d scanning techniques , <edu_end> such as structured light . <edu_end> phase - shifting is another effective descattering technique <edu_end> if the frequency of the projected pattern is sufficiently high . <edu_end> we demonstrate the performance of these two techniques and the combination of phase - shifting on scanning real - world translucent objects . <edu_end>
in the framework of a theory for invariant sensory signal representations , a signature <edu_end> which is invariant and selective for speech sounds can be obtained through projections in template signals <edu_end> and pooling over their transformations under a group . <edu_end> for locally compact groups , e.g. , translations , <edu_end> the theory explains the resilience of convolutional neural networks with filter weight sharing and max pooling across their local translations in frequency or time . <edu_end> in this paper we propose a discrimina - tive approach <edu_end> for learning an optimum set of templates , under a family of transformations , namely frequency transpositions and perturbations of the vocal tract length , <edu_end> which are among the primary sources of speech variability . <edu_end> implicitly , we generalize convolutional networks to transformations other than translations , <edu_end> and derive data - specific templates <edu_end> by training a deep network with convolution - pooling layers and densely connected layers . <edu_end> we demonstrate <edu_end> that such a convolutional networks , <edu_end> combining group - generalized convolutions , theoretical invariance guarantees and discriminative template selection , improves frame classification performance over standard translation - cnns and dnns on timit and wall street journal datasets . <edu_end>

this paper describes a crosslinguistic disfluency perception experiment . <edu_end> we tested the recognizability of pause fillers and partial words in english , german and mandarin . <edu_end> subjects were speakers of english with no knowledge of mandarin or ger - man . <edu_end> we found <edu_end> that subjects could identify disfluent from fluent utterances at a level above chance . <edu_end> pause fillers were easier to identify than partial words . <edu_end> accuracy rates were highest for english , <edu_end> followed by german and then mandarin . <edu_end> although german accuracy rates were higher than those for mandarin , <edu_end> discriminability analysis suggests <edu_end> that this is due to conservative bias towards false negatives rather than non - recognition of the acoustic material . <edu_end> the fact <edu_end> that subjects could identify dis - fluent speech in languages <edu_end> they did not know <edu_end> shows <edu_end> that there are real phonetic crosslinguistic cues to disfluency . <edu_end>
we address the problem <edu_end> of learning object class models and object segmentations from unannotated images . <edu_end> we introduce locus -lrb- learning object classes with unsupervised segmentation -rrb- which uses a generative probabilistic model <edu_end> to combine bottom - up cues of color and edge with top - down cues of shape and pose . <edu_end> a key aspect of this generative probabilistic model is that the object appearance is allowed to vary from image to image , <edu_end> allowing for significant within - class variation . <edu_end> by iteratively updating the belief in the object 's position , size , segmentation and pose , <edu_end> locus -lrb- learning object classes avoids making hard decisions about any of these quantities <edu_end> and so allows for each to be refined at any stage . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that locus -lrb- learning object classes successfully learns an object class model from unlabeled images , <edu_end> whilst also giving segmentation accuracies <edu_end> that rival existing supervised methods . <edu_end> finally , we demonstrate simultaneous recognition and segmentation in novel images <edu_end> using the learned models for a number of object classes , as well as unsupervised object discovery and tracking in video . <edu_end>

in natural speech , <edu_end> there is a moderate correlation between the fundamental frequency and formant frequencies across talkers . <edu_end> the present study used a high - quality vocoder <edu_end> to manipulate these properties <edu_end> and determine their contribution to perceived naturalness and voice gender . <edu_end> the stimuli were re - synthesized sentences <edu_end> spoken by two adult males and two adult females . <edu_end> scale factors <edu_end> were chosen for each sentence and for each talker to produce frequency - shifted versions with a specified mean fundamental frequency -lrb- f 0 -rrb- <edu_end> ranging from 60 hz to 450 hz in 10 steps , <edu_end> paired with 10 steps in geometric mean formant frequencies <edu_end> ranging from 850 hz to 2500 hz . <edu_end> listeners judged frequency - shifted sentences as more natural <edu_end> when f 0 and formant frequencies followed the co - variation of f 0 and formant frequencies in natural voices . <edu_end> sentences with low f 0 s and low formant frequencies were perceived as masculine , <edu_end> while sentences with high f 0 and high formant frequencies were assigned high ratings of femininity . <edu_end> sentences with '' mismatched '' f 0 and formant frequencies were assigned ratings near the midpoint of the range , <edu_end> indicating gender ambiguity . frequency - shifted sentences <edu_end> derived from male talkers <edu_end> received consistently higher ratings of masculinity than those <edu_end> derived from females , <edu_end> while sentences from female talkers received higher ratings of femininity , <edu_end> even when assigned scale factors appropriate for the opposite gender , <edu_end> indicating <edu_end> that factors other than f 0 and mean formant frequencies contribute to perceived gender . <edu_end>

protein interactions typically arise from a physical interaction of one or more small sites on the surface of the two proteins . <edu_end> identifying these sites <edu_end> is very important for drug and protein design . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we propose a computational method <edu_end> based on probabilistic relational model <edu_end> that attempts to address this task <edu_end> using high - throughput protein interaction data and a set of short sequence motifs . <edu_end> we learn the computational method <edu_end> using the em algorithm , with a branch - and - bound algorithm as an approximate inference for the e - step . <edu_end> our computational method searches for motifs <edu_end> whose presence in a pair of interacting proteins can explain their observed interaction . <edu_end> it also tries to determine which motif pairs have high affinity , <edu_end> and can therefore lead to an interaction . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that our computational method is more accurate than others <edu_end> at predicting new protein - protein interactions . <edu_end> more importantly , <edu_end> by examining solved structures of protein complexes , <edu_end> we find <edu_end> that 2/3 of the predicted active motifs correspond to actual interaction sites . <edu_end>

we propose a kernel - based method <edu_end> for finding matching between instances across different domains , such as multilingual documents and images with annotations . <edu_end> each instance is assumed to be represented as a multiset of features , e.g. , a bag - of - words representation for documents . <edu_end> the major difficulty <edu_end> in finding cross - domain relationships <edu_end> is that the similarity between instances in different domains can not be directly measured . <edu_end> to overcome this difficulty , <edu_end> the proposed kernel - based method embeds all the features of different domains in a shared latent space , <edu_end> and regards each instance as a distribution of its own features in the shared latent space . <edu_end> to represent the distributions efficiently and nonparametrically , <edu_end> we employ the framework of the kernel embeddings of distributions . <edu_end> the embedding is estimated <edu_end> so as to minimize the difference between distributions of paired instances <edu_end> while keeping unpaired instances apart . <edu_end> in our experiments , <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that the proposed kernel - based method can achieve high performance on finding correspondence between multilingual wikipedia articles , between documents and tags , and between images and tags . <edu_end>

our goal is to improve the training and prediction time of nyström method , <edu_end> which is a widely - used technique <edu_end> for generating low - rank kernel matrix approximations . <edu_end> when applying the nyström approximation for large - scale applications , <edu_end> both training and prediction time is dominated by computing kernel values between a data point and all landmark points . <edu_end> with m landmark points , <edu_end> this computation requires θ -lrb- md -rrb- time -lrb- flops -rrb- , <edu_end> where d is the input dimension . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we propose the use of a family of fast transforms <edu_end> to generate structured landmark points for nyström approximation . <edu_end> by exploiting fast transforms , <edu_end> e.g. , haar transform and hadamard transform , <edu_end> our modified nyström method requires only θ -lrb- m -rrb- or θ -lrb- m log d -rrb- time <edu_end> to compute the kernel values between a given data point and m landmark points . <edu_end> this improvement in time complexity can significantly speed up kernel approximation and benefit prediction speed in kernel machines . <edu_end> for instance , on the webspam data -lrb- more than 300,000 data points -rrb- , our proposed algorithm enables kernel svm prediction <edu_end> to deliver 98 % accuracy <edu_end> and the resulting prediction time is 1000 times faster than lib - svm and only 10 times slower than linear svm prediction -lrb- which yields only 91 % accuracy -rrb- . <edu_end>

matrices <edu_end> that collect the image coordinates of point features <edu_end> tracked through video <edu_end> -- one column per feature -- <edu_end> have often low rank , either exactly or approximately . <edu_end> this observation has led to many matrix factorization methods for 3d reconstruction , motion segmentation , or regularization of feature trajectories . <edu_end> however , temporary occlusions , image noise , and variations in lighting , pose , or object geometry often confound trackers . <edu_end> a feature <edu_end> that reappears <edu_end> after a temporary tracking failure <edu_end> -- whatever the cause -- <edu_end> is regarded as a new feature by typical tracking systems , <edu_end> resulting in very sparse matrices with many columns and rendering factorization problematic . <edu_end> we propose a method <edu_end> to simultaneously factor and compact such a matrix factorization methods <edu_end> by merging groups of columns <edu_end> that correspond to the same feature into single columns . <edu_end> this combination of compaction and factorization makes trackers more resilient to changes in appearance and short occlusions . <edu_end> preliminary experiments show <edu_end> that imputation of missing matrix entries <edu_end> -- and therefore matrix factorization -- <edu_end> becomes significantly more reliable as a result . <edu_end> clean column merging also required us to develop a history - sensitive feature reinitialization method <edu_end> we call feature snapping <edu_end> that aligns merged feature trajectory segments precisely to each other . <edu_end>

the estimation of surface emissivity and temperature from thermal hyperspectral data is a challenge . <edu_end> methods <edu_end> that estimate the temperature and emissivity on a pixel <edu_end> composed by one single material exist . <edu_end> however , the estimation of the temperature on a mixed pixel , i.e. a pixel <edu_end> composed by more than one material , <edu_end> is more complex <edu_end> and has scarcely been investigated in the literature . <edu_end> this paper addresses this issue <edu_end> by proposing an estimator <edu_end> which linearizes the black body law around the mean temperature of each material . <edu_end> the performance of this estimator is studied <edu_end> using simulated data with different hyperspectral sensor configurations and under various noise conditions . <edu_end> the obtained results are encouraging <edu_end> and show an accuracy on the estimated temperature of 0.5 k <edu_end> while using high spectral resolution sensor . <edu_end>

we propose to directly measure the importance of queries in the source domain to the target domain <edu_end> where no rank labels of documents are available , <edu_end> which is referred to as query weighting . <edu_end> query weighting is a key step <edu_end> in ranking model adaptation . <edu_end> as the learning object of ranking algorithms is divided by query instances , <edu_end> we argue <edu_end> that it 's more reasonable to conduct importance weighting at query level than document level . <edu_end> we present two query weighting schemes . <edu_end> the first compresses the query into a query feature vector , <edu_end> which aggregates all document instances in the same query , <edu_end> and then conducts query weighting <edu_end> based on the query feature vector . <edu_end> this query weighting schemes can efficiently estimate query importance <edu_end> by compressing query data , <edu_end> but the potential risk is information loss resulted from the compression . <edu_end> the second measures the similarity between the source query and each target query , <edu_end> and then combines these fine - grained similarity values for its importance estimation . <edu_end> adaptation experiments on letor3 .0 data set demonstrate <edu_end> that query weighting significantly outperforms document instance weighting methods . <edu_end>

we consider the problem of time difference of arrival estimation for cyclostationary signals in additive white gaussian noise . <edu_end> classical approaches to the problem <edu_end> either ignore the cyclostationarity <edu_end> and use ordinary cross - correlations , or exploit the cyclostationarity <edu_end> by using cyclic cross - correlations , <edu_end> or combine these approaches into a mul - ticycle approach . <edu_end> despite contradicting claims in the literature <edu_end> regarding the performance - ranking of these approaches , <edu_end> there has been almost no analytical comparative performance study . <edu_end> we propose to regard the estimated -lrb- ordinary or cyclic -rrb- correlations as the '' front - end '' data , <edu_end> and based on their asymptotically gaussian distribution , <edu_end> to compute the asymptotic cramér - rao bounds for the various combinations -lrb- ordinary / single - cycle / multi - cycle -rrb- . <edu_end> using our cyclic - correlations - based crb -lrb- termed '' crbcrb '' -rrb- , <edu_end> we can bound the performance of any -lrb- unbiased -rrb- estimator <edu_end> which exploits a given set of correlations . <edu_end> moreover , we propose an approximate maximum likelihood estimator -lrb- with respect to the correlations -rrb- , <edu_end> and show <edu_end> that approximate maximum likelihood estimator attains our crbcrb asymptotically in simulations , <edu_end> outperforming the competitors . <edu_end>

authorship attribution -lrb- authorship attribution -rrb- aims to identify the authors of a set of documents . <edu_end> traditional studies in this area often assume <edu_end> that there are a large set of labeled documents available for training . <edu_end> however , in the real life , it is often difficult or expensive to collect a large set of labeled data . <edu_end> for example , in the online review domain , most reviewers -lrb- authors -rrb- only write a few reviews , <edu_end> which are not enough <edu_end> to serve as the training data for accurate classification . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we present a novel three - view tri - training method <edu_end> to iteratively identify authors of unlabeled data <edu_end> to augment the training set . <edu_end> the key idea is to first represent each document in three distinct views , <edu_end> and then perform tri - training <edu_end> to exploit the large amount of un - labeled documents . <edu_end> starting from 10 training documents per author , <edu_end> we systematically evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed three - view tri - training method for authorship attribution . <edu_end> experimental results show <edu_end> that the proposed three - view tri - training method outperforms the state - of - the - art semi - supervised method cng+svm and other baselines . <edu_end>
conflict escalation in multi - party conversations refers to an increase in the intensity of conflict during conversations . <edu_end> here we study annotation and detection of conflict escalation in broadcast political debates towards a machine - mediated conflict management system . <edu_end> in this regard , we label conflict escalation <edu_end> using crowd - sourced annotations <edu_end> and predict it with automatically extracted conversational and prosodic features . <edu_end> in particular , <edu_end> to annotate the conflict escalation <edu_end> we deploy two different strategies , i.e. , indirect inference and direct assessment ; <edu_end> the direct assessment method refers to a way <edu_end> that annotators watch and compare two consecutive clips during the annotation process , <edu_end> while the indirect inference method indicates <edu_end> that each clip is independently annotated with respect to the level of conflict <edu_end> then the level conflict escalation is inferred <edu_end> by comparing annotations of two consecutive clips . <edu_end> empirical results with 792 pairs of consecutive clips <edu_end> in classifying three types of conflict escalation , i.e. , escalation , de - escalation , and constant , show <edu_end> that labels from direct assessment yield higher classification performance -lrb- 45.3 % unweighted accuracy -lrb- ua -rrb- -rrb- than the one from indirect inference -lrb- 39.7 % ua -rrb- , <edu_end> although the annotations from both methods are highly correlated -lrb- ρ = 0.74 in continuous values and 63 % agreement in ternary classes -rrb- . <edu_end>

state transition matrices as used in standard hmm decoders <edu_end> have two widely perceived limitations . <edu_end> one is that the implicit geometric state duration distributions <edu_end> which they model <edu_end> do not accurately reflect true duration distributions . <edu_end> the other is that they impose no hard limit on maximum duration with the result <edu_end> that state transition probabilities often have little influence <edu_end> when combined with acoustic probabilities , <edu_end> which are of a different order of magnitude . <edu_end> explicit duration models were developed in the past <edu_end> to address the first problem . <edu_end> these were not widely taken up <edu_end> because their performance advantage in clean speech recognition was often not sufficiently great <edu_end> to offset the extra complexity <edu_end> which they introduced . <edu_end> however , duration models have much greater potential <edu_end> when applied to noisy speech recognition . <edu_end> in explicit duration model paper we present a simple and generic form of explicit duration model <edu_end> and show <edu_end> that explicit duration model leads to strong performance improvements <edu_end> when applied to connected digit recognition in noise . <edu_end>
the hard thresholding pursuit is a class of truncated gradient descent methods <edu_end> for finding sparse solutions of ℓ 0-constrained loss minimization problems . <edu_end> the htp - style methods have been shown to have strong approximation guarantee and impressive numerical performance in high dimensional statistical learning applications . <edu_end> however , the current theoretical treatment of these htp - style methods has traditionally been restricted to the analysis of parameter estimation consistency . <edu_end> it remains an open problem <edu_end> to analyze the support recovery performance -lrb- a.k.a . , sparsistency -rrb- of this type of htp - style methods <edu_end> for recovering the global minimizer of the original np - hard problem . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we bridge this gap <edu_end> by showing , for the first time , <edu_end> that exact recovery of the global sparse minimizer is possible for htp - style methods under restricted strong condition number bounding conditions . <edu_end> we further show <edu_end> that htp - style methods are able to recover the support of certain relaxed sparse solutions <edu_end> without assuming bounded restricted strong condition number . <edu_end> numerical results on simulated data confirms our theoretical predictions . <edu_end>

in this paper , we introduce a similarity metric for curved shapes <edu_end> that can be described , distinctively , by ordered points . <edu_end> the proposed similarity metric represents a given curve as a point in the deformation space , the direct product of rigid transformation matrices , such <edu_end> that the successive action of the matrices on a fixed starting point reconstructs the full curve . <edu_end> in general , both open and closed curves are represented in the deformation space modulo shape orientation and orientation <edu_end> preserving diffeomorphisms . <edu_end> the use of direct product lie groups <edu_end> to represent curved shapes <edu_end> led to an explicit formula for geodesic curves and the formulation of a similarity metric between shapes by the l 2-norm on the lie algebra . <edu_end> additionally , invariance to reparametrization or estimation of point correspondence between shapes is performed as an intermediate step for computing geodesics . <edu_end> furthermore , <edu_end> since there is no computation of differential quantities on the curves , <edu_end> our direct product lie groups is more robust to local perturbations <edu_end> and needs no pre - smoothing . <edu_end> we compare our similarity metric with the elastic shape metric <edu_end> defined through the square root velocity mapping , and other shape matching approaches . <edu_end>

magnetic resonant coupling -lrb- mrc -rrb- is an efficient method <edu_end> for realizing the near - field wireless power transfer . <edu_end> the use of multiple transmitters -lrb- txs -rrb- each with one coil can be applied <edu_end> to enhance the wpt performance <edu_end> by focusing the magnetic fields from all tx coils in a beam toward the receiver coil , <edu_end> termed as '' magnetic beamforming '' . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we study the optimal magnetic beamforming for an mrc - wpt system with multiple txs and a single rx . <edu_end> we formulate an optimization problem <edu_end> to jointly design the currents <edu_end> flowing through different txs <edu_end> so as to minimize the total power <edu_end> drawn from their voltage sources , <edu_end> subject to the minimum power <edu_end> required by the rx load as well as the txs ' constraints on the peak voltage and current . for the special case of identical tx resistances <edu_end> and neglecting all txs ' constraints on the peak voltage and current , <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that the optimal current magnitude of each magnetic resonant coupling is proportional to the mutual inductance between its tx coil and the rx coil . <edu_end> in general , the problem is a non - convex quadratically constrained quadratic programming -lrb- qcqp -rrb- problem , <edu_end> which is reformulated as a semidefinite programming problem . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that its semidefinite relaxation is tight . <edu_end> numerical results show <edu_end> that magnetic beamforming significantly enhances the deliverable power as well as the wpt efficiency over the uncoordinated benchmark scheme of equal current allocation . <edu_end>

complexity theory of circuits strongly suggests <edu_end> that deep architectures can be much more efficient -lrb- sometimes exponentially -rrb- than shallow architectures , in terms of computational elements <edu_end> required to represent some functions . <edu_end> deep multi - layer neural networks have many levels of non - linearities <edu_end> allowing them to compactly represent highly non - linear and highly - varying functions . <edu_end> however , <edu_end> until recently it was not clear how to train such deep architectures , <edu_end> since gradient - based optimization <edu_end> starting from random initialization <edu_end> appears to often get stuck in poor solutions . <edu_end> hin - ton et al . <edu_end> recently introduced a greedy layer - wise unsupervised learning algorithm for deep belief networks , a generative model with many layers of hidden causal variables . in the context of the above optimization problem , we study this algorithm empirically <edu_end> and explore variants <edu_end> to better understand its success <edu_end> and extend it to cases <edu_end> where the inputs are continuous <edu_end> or where the structure of the input distribution is not revealing enough about the variable <edu_end> to be predicted in a supervised task . <edu_end> our experiments also confirm the hypothesis <edu_end> that the greedy layer - wise unsu - pervised training strategy mostly helps the optimization , <edu_end> by initializing weights in a region near a good local minimum , <edu_end> giving rise to internal distributed representations <edu_end> that are high - level abstractions of the input , <edu_end> bringing better generalization . <edu_end>
one of the most important crowdsourcing topics is to study the effective quality control methods <edu_end> so as to reduce the cost <edu_end> and to guarantee the quality of task processing . <edu_end> as an effective approach , iterative improvement workflow is known to choose the best result from multiple workflows . <edu_end> however , for complex crowdsourcing tasks <edu_end> that consists of a certain number of subtasks under some specific constraints , <edu_end> but can not be split into subtasks <edu_end> to be crowdsourced , <edu_end> the approach merely considers the best workflow <edu_end> without integrating the contributions of all workflows , <edu_end> which potentially results in extra costs for more iterations . <edu_end> in this paper , we propose an assembly model <edu_end> to integrate the best output of subtasks from different workflows . <edu_end> moreover , we devise an efficient iterative method <edu_end> based on pomdp <edu_end> to improve the quality of assembled output . <edu_end> empirical studies confirms the superiority of our proposed assembly model . <edu_end>

in this paper , we propose a new deep hashing approach <edu_end> to learn compact binary codes for large scale visual search . <edu_end> unlike most existing binary codes learning methods <edu_end> which seek a single linear projection <edu_end> to map each sample into a binary vector , <edu_end> we develop a deep neural network <edu_end> to seek multiple hierarchical non - linear transformations <edu_end> to learn these binary codes , <edu_end> so that the nonlinear relationship of samples can be well exploited . <edu_end> our deep hashing approach is learned under three constraints at the top layer of the deep neural network : <edu_end> 1 -rrb- the loss between the original real - valued feature descrip - tor and the learned binary vector is minimized , <edu_end> 2 -rrb- the binary codes distribute evenly on each bit , <edu_end> and 3 -rrb- different bits are as independent as possible . <edu_end> to further improve the dis - criminative power of the learned binary codes , <edu_end> we extend dh into supervised dh by including one discrimi - native term into the objective function of dh <edu_end> which simultaneously maximizes the inter - class variations <edu_end> and minimizes the intra - class variations of the learned binary codes . <edu_end> experimental results show the superiority of the proposed deep hashing approach over the state - of - the - arts . <edu_end>
we present a novel method for the discovery and statistical representation of motion patterns in a scene <edu_end> observed by a static camera . <edu_end> related methods <edu_end> involving learning of patterns of activity <edu_end> rely on trajectories <edu_end> obtained from object detection and tracking systems , <edu_end> which are unreliable in complex scenes of crowded motion . <edu_end> we propose a gaussian mixture model model representation of salient patterns of optical flow , <edu_end> and present an algorithm <edu_end> for learning these patterns from dense optical flow in a hierarchical , unsupervised fashion . <edu_end> using low level cues of noisy optical flow , <edu_end> k - means is employed <edu_end> to initialize a gaussian mixture model for temporally segmented clips of video . <edu_end> the components of this gaussian mixture model are then filtered <edu_end> and instances of motion patterns are computed <edu_end> using a simple motion model , <edu_end> by linking components across space and time . <edu_end> motion patterns are then initialized <edu_end> and membership of instances in different motion patterns is established <edu_end> by using kl divergence between gaussian mixture model distributions of pattern instances . <edu_end> finally , a pixel level representation of motion patterns is proposed <edu_end> by deriving conditional expectation of optical flow . <edu_end> results of extensive experiments are presented for multiple surveillance sequences <edu_end> containing numerous patterns <edu_end> involving both pedestrian and vehicular traffic . <edu_end>
in the form of topic discussions , users interact with each other <edu_end> to share knowledge and exchange information in online forums . <edu_end> modeling the evolution of topic discussion reveals <edu_end> how information propagates on internet <edu_end> and can thus help understand sociological phenomena <edu_end> and improve the performance of applications such as recommendation systems . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we argue <edu_end> that a user 's participation in topic discussions is motivated by either her friends or her own preferences . <edu_end> inspired by the theory of information flow , <edu_end> we propose dynamic topic discussion models <edu_end> by mining influential relationships between users and individual preferences . <edu_end> reply relations of users are exploited <edu_end> to construct the fundamental influential social network . <edu_end> the property of discussed topics and time lapse factor are also considered in our dynamic topic discussion models . <edu_end> furthermore , we propose a novel measure <edu_end> called participationrank <edu_end> to rank users <edu_end> according to how important they are in the social network and to what extent they prefer to participate in the discussion of a certain topic . <edu_end> the experiments show <edu_end> our model can simulate the evolution of topic discussions well <edu_end> and predict the tendency of user 's participation accurately . <edu_end>

many problems have a huge state space and no good heuristic <edu_end> to order moves <edu_end> so as to guide the search toward the best positions . <edu_end> random games can be used <edu_end> to score positions <edu_end> and evaluate their interest . <edu_end> random games can also be improved <edu_end> using random games to choose a move <edu_end> to try at each step of a game . <edu_end> nested monte - carlo search addresses the problem <edu_end> of guiding the search toward better states <edu_end> when there is no available heuristic . <edu_end> nested monte - carlo search uses nested levels of random games <edu_end> in order to guide the search . <edu_end> the nested monte - carlo search is studied theoretically on simple abstract problems <edu_end> and applied successfully to three different games : <edu_end> morpion solitaire , samegame and 16x16 sudoku . <edu_end>
good sparse approximations are essential for practical inference in gaussian processes <edu_end> as the computational cost of exact methods is prohibitive for large datasets . <edu_end> the fully independent training conditional and the variational free energy approximations are two recent popular methods . <edu_end> despite superficial similarities , <edu_end> these approximations have surprisingly different theoretical properties <edu_end> and behave differently in practice . <edu_end> we thoroughly investigate the two methods for regression both analytically and through illustrative examples , <edu_end> and draw conclusions <edu_end> to guide practical application . <edu_end>
we present a novel approach to non - rigid structure from motion -lrb- nrsfm -rrb- from an orthographic video sequence , <edu_end> based on a new interpretation of the problem . <edu_end> existing approaches assume <edu_end> the object shape space is well - <edu_end> modeled by a linear subspace . <edu_end> our approach only assumes <edu_end> that small neighborhoods of shapes are well - modeled with a linear subspace . <edu_end> this constrains the shapes <edu_end> to belong to a man - ifold of dimensionality equal to the number of degrees of freedom of the object . <edu_end> after showing <edu_end> that the problem is still overconstrained , <edu_end> we present a solution <edu_end> composed of a novel initialization algorithm , <edu_end> followed by a robust extension of the locally smooth manifold learning algorithm <edu_end> tailored to the nrsfm problem . <edu_end> we finally present some test cases <edu_end> where the linear basis method fails -lrb- and is actually not meant to work -rrb- <edu_end> while the proposed approach is successful . <edu_end>
we present a novel framework , <edu_end> called grab -lrb- graphical models with overlapping blocks -rrb- , <edu_end> to capture densely connected components in a network estimate . <edu_end> grab takes as input a data matrix of p variables and n samples <edu_end> and jointly learns both a network of the p variables and densely connected groups of variables <edu_end> -lrb- called ` blocks ' -rrb- . <edu_end> grab has four major novelties <edu_end> as compared to existing network estimation methods : <edu_end> 1 -rrb- it does not require blocks <edu_end> to be given a priori . <edu_end> 2 -rrb- blocks can overlap . <edu_end> 3 -rrb- it can jointly learn a network structure and overlapping blocks . <edu_end> 4 -rrb- it solves a joint optimization problem with the block coordinate descent method <edu_end> that is convex in each step . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that grab reveals the underlying network structure substantially better than four state - of - the - art competitors on synthetic data . <edu_end> when applied to cancer gene expression data , <edu_end> grab outperforms its competitors <edu_end> in revealing known functional gene sets and potentially novel cancer driver genes . <edu_end>
we consider stochastic multi - armed bandits <edu_end> where the expected reward is a unimodal function over partially ordered arms . <edu_end> this important class of problems has been recently inves - the set of arms is either discrete , <edu_end> in which case arms correspond to the vertices of a finite graph <edu_end> whose structure represents similarity in rewards , or continuous , <edu_end> in which case arms belong to a bounded interval . <edu_end> for discrete unimodal bandits , <edu_end> we derive asymptotic lower bounds for the regret <edu_end> achieved under any algorithm , <edu_end> and propose osub , an algorithm <edu_end> whose regret matches this lower bound . <edu_end> our algorithm optimally exploits the unimodal structure of the problem , <edu_end> and surprisingly , its asymptotic regret does not depend on the number of arms . <edu_end> we also provide a regret upper bound for osub in non - stationary environments <edu_end> where the expected rewards smoothly evolve over time . <edu_end> the analytical results are supported by numerical experiments <edu_end> showing <edu_end> that osub performs significantly better than the state - of - the - art algorithms . <edu_end> for continuous sets of arms , <edu_end> we provide a brief discussion . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that combining an appropriate discretization of the set of arms with the ucb algorithm yields an order - optimal regret , <edu_end> and in practice , outperforms recently proposed algorithms <edu_end> designed to exploit the unimodal structure . <edu_end>
we propose a generalized gaussian process model , <edu_end> which is a unifying framework <edu_end> that encompasses many existing gaussian process models , such as gp regression , classification , and counting . <edu_end> in the generalized gaussian process model , the observation likelihood of the gaussian process models is itself parameterized <edu_end> using the exponential family distribution . <edu_end> by deriving approximate inference algorithms for the generalized gp model , <edu_end> we are able to easily apply the same generalized gaussian process model to all other gaussian process models . <edu_end> novel gaussian process models are created <edu_end> by changing the parameterization of the likelihood function , <edu_end> which greatly simplifies their creation for task - specific output domains . <edu_end> we also derive a closed - form efficient taylor approximation for inference on the generalized gaussian process model , <edu_end> and draw interesting connections with other model - specific closed - form approximations . <edu_end> finally , using the generalized gaussian process model , <edu_end> we create several new gaussian process models <edu_end> and show their efficacy <edu_end> in building task - specific gp models for computer vision . <edu_end>
many clustering algorithms only find one clustering solution . <edu_end> however , data can often be grouped <edu_end> and interpreted in many different ways . <edu_end> this is particularly true in the high - dimensional setting <edu_end> where different subspaces reveal different possible groupings of the data . <edu_end> instead of committing to one clustering solution , <edu_end> here we introduce a novel method <edu_end> that can provide several non - redundant clustering solutions to the user . <edu_end> our approach simultaneously learns non - redundant subspaces <edu_end> that provide multiple views <edu_end> and finds a clustering solution in each view . <edu_end> we achieve this <edu_end> by augmenting a spectral clustering objective function <edu_end> to incorporate dimensionality reduction and multiple views <edu_end> and to penalize for redundancy between the views . <edu_end>
this paper addresses view - invariant object detection and pose estimation from a single image . <edu_end> while recent work fo - cuses on object - centered representations of point - based object features , <edu_end> we revisit the viewer - centered framework , <edu_end> and use image contours as basic features . <edu_end> given training examples of arbitrary views of an object , <edu_end> we learn a sparse object model in terms of a few view - dependent shape templates . <edu_end> the sparse object model are jointly used for detecting object occurrences <edu_end> and estimating their 3d poses in a new image . <edu_end> instrumental to this is our new mid - level feature , <edu_end> called bag of boundaries , <edu_end> aimed at lifting from individual edges toward their more informative summaries <edu_end> for identifying object boundaries amidst the background clutter . <edu_end> in inference , bobs are placed on deformable grids both in the image and the sparse object model , <edu_end> and then matched . <edu_end> this is formulated as a convex optimization problem <edu_end> that accommodates invariance to non - rigid , locally affine shape deformations . <edu_end> evaluation on benchmark datasets demonstrates our competitive results relative to the state of the art . <edu_end>
