a new characteristic waveform decomposition method <edu_end> based on wavelets <edu_end> is proposed for the waveform interpolation paradigm . <edu_end> in waveform interpolation paradigm , pitch - cycle waveforms are filtered in the evolution domain <edu_end> to decompose the signal into two waveform surfaces , <edu_end> one characterising voiced speech <edu_end> and a second <edu_end> representing unvoiced speech . <edu_end> the slow roll - off of fir filters leads , however , to a significant interrelationship between the decomposed surfaces . <edu_end> here we present the pitch synchronous wavelet <edu_end> transform as an alternative decomposition mechanism . <edu_end> filtering is again performed in the evolutionary waveform domain , <edu_end> producing characteristic surfaces at several resolutions . <edu_end> this multi - scale characterisation leads to more flexible quantisation of parameters , especially at higher rates than waveform interpolation paradigm 's 2.4 kb / s . <edu_end> fir filters are replaced in the wavelet filter bank by causal , stable iir filters <edu_end> which achieve significant delay reductions over their fir counterparts . <edu_end> furthermore , iir filters track the dynamic aspects of the evolutionary surfaces faster , <edu_end> overcoming problems <edu_end> existing in the current wi decomposition . <edu_end>

planned experiments are the gold standard <edu_end> in reliably comparing the causal effect <edu_end> of switching from a baseline policy to a new ad pricing policy . <edu_end> one critical shortcoming of classical experimental methods , however , is that they typically do not take into account the dynamic nature of response to policy changes . <edu_end> for instance , in an experiment <edu_end> where we seek to understand the effects of a new ad pricing policy on auction revenue , <edu_end> agents may adapt their bidding in response to the experimental pricing changes . <edu_end> thus , causal effects of the new ad pricing policy after such adaptation period , the long - term causal effects , are not captured by the classical methodology <edu_end> even though they clearly are more indicative of the value of the new ad pricing policy . <edu_end> here , <edu_end> we formalize a framework <edu_end> to define and estimate long - term causal effects of policy changes in multiagent economies . <edu_end> central to our approach is behavioral game theory , <edu_end> which we leverage <edu_end> to formulate the ignorability assumptions <edu_end> that are necessary for causal inference . <edu_end> under such ignorability assumptions <edu_end> we estimate long - term causal effects through a latent space approach , <edu_end> where a behavioral model of how agents act conditional on their latent behaviors <edu_end> is combined with a temporal model <edu_end> of how behaviors evolve over time . <edu_end>

this paper tackles an important aspect of the variational problems <edu_end> involving active contours , <edu_end> which has been largely overlooked so far : <edu_end> the optimization by gradient flows . classically , the definition of a gradient depends directly on the choice of an inner product structure . <edu_end> this consideration is largely absent from the active contours literature . <edu_end> most authors , overtly or covertly , assume <edu_end> that the space of admissible deformations is ruled by the canonical l 2 inner product . <edu_end> the classical gradient flows <edu_end> reported in the literature <edu_end> are relative to this particular choice . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we investigate the relevance <edu_end> of using other inner products , <edu_end> yielding other gradient descents , <edu_end> and some other minimizing flows <edu_end> not deriving from any inner product . <edu_end> in particular , we show <edu_end> how to induce different degrees of spatial coherence into the minimizing flow , <edu_end> in order to decrease the probability <edu_end> of getting trapped into irrelevant local minima . <edu_end> we show with some numerical experiments <edu_end> that the sensitivity of the active contours method to initial conditions , <edu_end> which seriously limits its applicability and its efficiency , <edu_end> is alleviated by our application - specific spatially coherent minimizing flows . <edu_end>

in social choice settings with strict preferences , random dictatorship rules were characterized by gibbard -lsb- 1977 -rsb- as the only randomized social choice functions <edu_end> that satisfy strategyproofness and ex post efficiency . in the more general domain with indifferences , <edu_end> rsd -lrb- random serial dictatorship -rrb- rules are the well - known and perhaps only known generalization of random dictatorship . <edu_end> we present a new generalization of random dictatorship for indifferences <edu_end> called maximal recursive rule as an alternative to rsd . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that maximal recursive rule is polynomial - time computable , weakly strategyproof with respect to stochastic dominance , <edu_end> and , in some respects , outperforms rsd on efficiency . <edu_end>
this paper investigates a new approach <edu_end> for training discriminant classifiers <edu_end> when only a small set of labeled data is available together with a large set of unlabeled data . <edu_end> this algorithm optimizes the classification maximum likelihood of a set of labeled - unlabeled data , <edu_end> using a variant form of the classification expectation maximization algorithm . <edu_end> its originality is that it makes use of both un - labeled data and of a probabilistic misclassification model for these data . <edu_end> the parameters of the label - error model are learned together with the classifier parameters . <edu_end> we demonstrate the effectiveness of the approach on four data - sets <edu_end> and show the advantages of this method over a previously developed semi - supervised algorithm <edu_end> which does not consider imperfections in the labeling process . <edu_end>

transduction is an inference principle <edu_end> that takes a training sample <edu_end> and aims at estimating the values of a function at given points <edu_end> contained in the so - called working sample <edu_end> as opposed to the whole of input space for induction . <edu_end> transduction provides a confidence measure on single predictions rather than classifiers - a feature particularly important for risk - sensitive applications . <edu_end> the possibly infinite number of functions is reduced to a finite number of equivalence classes on the working sample . <edu_end> a rigorous bayesian analysis reveals <edu_end> that for standard classification loss we can not benefit from considering more than one test point at a time . <edu_end> the probability of the label of a given test point is determined as the posterior measure of the corresponding subset of hypothesis space . <edu_end> we consider the pac setting of binary classification by linear discriminant functions -lrb- perceptrons -rrb- in kernel space such that the probability of labels is determined by the volume ratio in version space . <edu_end> we suggest to sample this region by an ergodic billiard . <edu_end> experimental results on real world data indicate <edu_end> that bayesian analysis compares favourably to the well - known support vector machine , <edu_end> in particular if the posterior probability of labellings is used as a confidence measure <edu_end> to exclude test points of low confidence . <edu_end>

in order to properly regulate iterated belief revision , darwiche and pearl -lrb- 1997 -rrb- model belief revision <edu_end> as revising epistemic states by propositions . <edu_end> an epistemic state in their sense consists of a belief set and a set of conditional beliefs . <edu_end> although the denotation of an epis - temic state can be indirectly captured by a total preorder on the set of worlds , <edu_end> it is unclear how to directly capture the structure in terms of the beliefs and conditional beliefs <edu_end> it contains . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we first provide an ax - iomatic characterisation for epistemic states <edu_end> by using nine rules about beliefs and conditional beliefs , <edu_end> and then argue <edu_end> that the last two rules are too strong <edu_end> and should be eliminated <edu_end> for characterising the belief state of an agent . <edu_end> we call a structure <edu_end> which satisfies the first seven rules a general epistemic state . <edu_end> to provide a semantical characterisation of geps , <edu_end> we introduce a mathematical structure <edu_end> called belief algebra , <edu_end> which is in essence a certain binary relation <edu_end> defined on the power set of worlds . <edu_end> we then establish a 1 - 1 correspondence between epistemic state and belief algebras , <edu_end> and show <edu_end> that total preorders on worlds are special cases of belief algebras . <edu_end> furthermore , using the notion of belief algebras , <edu_end> we extend the classical iterated belief revision rules of darwiche and pearl to our setting of general epistemic states . <edu_end>

this paper introduces an approach <edu_end> of creating face makeup upon a face image with another image as the style example . <edu_end> our approach is analogous to physical makeup , <edu_end> as we modify the color and skin detail <edu_end> while preserving the face structure . <edu_end> more precisely , we first decompose the two images into three layers : <edu_end> face structure layer , skin detail layer , and color layer . <edu_end> thereafter , we transfer information from each layer of one image to corresponding layer of the other image . <edu_end> one major advantage of the proposed method lies in that only one example image is required . <edu_end> this renders face makeup by example very convenient and practical . <edu_end> equally , this enables some additional interesting applications , <edu_end> such as applying makeup by a portraiture . <edu_end> the experiment results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach <edu_end> in faithfully transferring makeup . <edu_end>

two seemingly contradictory theories attempt <edu_end> to explain <edu_end> how humans move <edu_end> to intercept an airborne ball . <edu_end> one theory posits <edu_end> that humans predict the ball trajectory <edu_end> to optimally plan future actions ; <edu_end> the other claims <edu_end> that , <edu_end> instead of performing such complicated computations , <edu_end> humans employ heuristics <edu_end> to reactively choose appropriate actions <edu_end> based on immediate visual feedback . <edu_end> in this paper , we show <edu_end> that interception strategies appearing to be heuristics can be understood as computational solutions to the optimal control problem <edu_end> faced by a ball - catching agent <edu_end> acting under uncertainty . <edu_end> modeling catching as a continuous partially observable markov decision process <edu_end> and employing stochastic optimal control theory , <edu_end> we discover <edu_end> that the four main heuristics <edu_end> described in the literature <edu_end> are optimal solutions <edu_end> if the catcher has sufficient time <edu_end> to continuously visually track the ball . <edu_end> specifically , by varying model parameters such as noise , time to ground contact , and perceptual latency , <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that different strategies arise under different circumstances . <edu_end> the catcher 's policy switches between generating reactive and predictive behavior <edu_end> based on the ratio of system to observation noise and the ratio between reaction time and task duration . <edu_end> thus , we provide a rational account of human ball - catching behavior and a unifying explanation for seemingly contradictory theories of target interception on the basis of stochastic optimal control . <edu_end>

'' . <edu_end> the most commonly used approach to speaker diarization is agglomerative clustering of multiple initial clusters . <edu_end> even though the initial clustering is greatly modified by iterative cluster merging and possibly multiple resegmentations of the data , <edu_end> the initialization algorithm is a key module for system performance and robustness . <edu_end> in this paper we present a novel approach <edu_end> that obtains a desired initial number of clusters in three steps . <edu_end> it first computes possible speaker change points via a standard technique <edu_end> based on the bayesian information criterion . <edu_end> it then classifies the resulting segments into '' friend '' and '' enemy '' groups <edu_end> to finally creates an initial set of clusters for the system . <edu_end> we test this algorithm with the dataset <edu_end> used in the rt05s evaluation , <edu_end> where we show a 13 % diarization error rate relative improvement and a 2.5 % absolute cluster purity improvement with respect to our previous algorithm . <edu_end>

this paper addresses the problem of the supervised signal classification , <edu_end> by using a hierarchical bayesian method . <edu_end> each signal is characterized by a set of parameters , the features , <edu_end> which are estimated from a set of learning signals . <edu_end> moreover , these parameters are distributed <edu_end> according to a class - specific posterior distribution <edu_end> which allows one to capture the variability of the features within the same class . <edu_end> within the hierarchical bayesian method , the feature extraction step and the learning step can be performed jointly . <edu_end> unfortunately , the estimation of the class - specific distribution parameters requires the computation of intractable multi - dimensional integrals . <edu_end> then a markov - chain monte carlo algorithm is used <edu_end> to sample the posterior distributions of the features over all the training signals of each class . <edu_end> an application to electrical transient classification for non - intrusive load monitoring is introduced . <edu_end> simulations over real - world electrical transients signals are driven <edu_end> and show the capacity of the proposed markov - chain monte carlo algorithm <edu_end> to discriminate two classes of transients . <edu_end>
digital fingerprinting is an effective method <edu_end> to identify users <edu_end> who might try to redistribute multimedia content , such as images and video . <edu_end> these digital fingerprinting are typically embedded into the content <edu_end> using watermarking techniques <edu_end> that are designed to be robust to a variety of attacks . <edu_end> a cheap and effective attack against such digital fingerprints is collusion , <edu_end> where several differently marked copies of the same content are averaged <edu_end> or combined <edu_end> to disrupt the underlying fingerprint . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we study the problem <edu_end> of designing fingerprints <edu_end> that can withstand collusion , <edu_end> yet trace colluders . <edu_end> since , in antipodal cdma - type watermarking , <edu_end> the correlation contributions only decrease <edu_end> where watermarks differ , <edu_end> by constructing binary code vectors <edu_end> where any subset of k or fewer of these vectors have unique overlap , <edu_end> we may identify groups of k or less colluders . <edu_end> our construction of such anti - collusion codes uses the theory of combinatorial designs , <edu_end> and for n users requires o -lrb- √ n -rrb- bits . <edu_end> further , <edu_end> we explore a block matrix structure for the anti - collusion codes <edu_end> that reduces the computational complexity <edu_end> for identifying colluders <edu_end> and improves the detection capability <edu_end> when colluders belong to the same subgroup . <edu_end>
we study an interesting and challenging problem , online streaming feature selection , <edu_end> in which the size of the feature set is unknown , <edu_end> and not all features are available for learning <edu_end> while leaving the number of observations constant . <edu_end> in this problem , the candidate features arrive one at a time , <edu_end> and the learner 's task is to select a '' best so far '' set of features from streaming features . <edu_end> standard feature selection methods can not perform well in this scenario . <edu_end> thus , we present a novel framework <edu_end> based on feature relevance . <edu_end> under this framework , a promising alternative method , online streaming feature selection -lrb- osfs -rrb- , is presented to online select strongly relevant and non - redundant features . <edu_end> in addition to osfs , a faster fast - osfs algorithm is proposed <edu_end> to further improve the selection efficiency . <edu_end> experimental results show <edu_end> that our algorithms achieve more compactness and better accuracy than existing streaming feature selection algorithms on various datasets . <edu_end>
the goal of decentralized optimization over a network is to optimize a global objective <edu_end> formed by a sum of local -lrb- possibly nonsmooth -rrb- convex functions <edu_end> using only local computation and communication . <edu_end> we develop and analyze distributed algorithms <edu_end> based on dual averaging of subgradients , <edu_end> and provide sharp bounds on their convergence rates as a function of the network size and topology . <edu_end> our analysis clearly separates the convergence of the optimization algorithm itself from the effects of communication constraints <edu_end> arising from the network structure . <edu_end> we show <edu_end> that the number of iterations <edu_end> required by our algorithm <edu_end> scales inversely in the spectral gap of the network . <edu_end> the sharpness of this prediction is confirmed both by theoretical lower bounds and simulations for various networks . <edu_end>
natural images are approximately scale invariant <edu_end> resulting in long range statistical regularities <edu_end> that typically obey a power law . <edu_end> for example , images have considerable regularity in their second order spatial correlations <edu_end> as measured by the power spectrum . <edu_end> processing images <edu_end> to remove these expected correlations <edu_end> is known as whitening an image . <edu_end> because the expected value of the power spectrum has a regular form -lrb- a power law -rrb- linear processing such as con - volution can be used <edu_end> to whiten an image . <edu_end> after whitening an image , <edu_end> higher order regularities <edu_end> that can not be removed with linear processing <edu_end> still exist in the form of correlations in the magnitude . <edu_end> in this paper <edu_end> it is shown <edu_end> that these correlations also obey a power law and a non - linear method is used <edu_end> to remove them , <edu_end> a process <edu_end> referred to as higher order whitening . <edu_end> the method is invertible <edu_end> demonstrating <edu_end> that <edu_end> while redundancy is removed <edu_end> no information is lost . <edu_end> experiments are given showing <edu_end> that after higher order whitening the coefficients can be severely quantized <edu_end> yet a good reconstruction is possible despite the nonlinearities . <edu_end>

ensembles of randomized decision trees , <edu_end> usually referred to as random forests , <edu_end> are widely used for classification and regression tasks in machine learning and statistics . <edu_end> random forests achieve competitive predictive performance <edu_end> and are computationally efficient <edu_end> to train and test , <edu_end> making random forests excellent candidates for real - world prediction tasks . <edu_end> the most popular random forest variants -lrb- such as breiman 's random forest and extremely randomized trees -rrb- operate on batches of training data . <edu_end> online methods are now in greater demand . <edu_end> existing online random forests , however , require more training data than their batch counterpart <edu_end> to achieve comparable predictive performance . <edu_end> in this work , <edu_end> we use mondrian processes -lrb- roy and teh , 2009 -rrb- <edu_end> to construct ensembles of random decision trees <edu_end> we call mondrian forests . <edu_end> mondrian forests can be grown in an incremental / online fashion <edu_end> and remarkably , the distribution of online mondrian forests is the same as that of batch mondrian forests . <edu_end> mondrian forests achieve competitive predictive performance <edu_end> comparable with existing online random forests <edu_end> and periodically retrained batch random forests , <edu_end> while being more than an order of magnitude faster , <edu_end> thus representing a better computation vs accuracy tradeoff . <edu_end>

in this paper , we propose a novel nonparametric modeling technique , namely space kernel analysis , <edu_end> as a result of the definition of the space kernel . <edu_end> we analyze the uncertainty of space kernel analysis <edu_end> and show <edu_end> that space kernel analysis is subjected to the bias / variance dilemma . <edu_end> nevertheless , we demonstrate <edu_end> that , by a proper choice of the space kernel matrix , space kernel analysis is able to balance between the robustness and accuracy <edu_end> and hence outperforms other kernel - based learning methods . <edu_end> the cost function of space kernel analysis is derived , <edu_end> and it proves that space kernel analysis minimizes the weighted least squared cost function <edu_end> whose weight matrix is diagonal <edu_end> and determined by the space kernel matrix . <edu_end> the parallels between space kernel analysis and several other nonparametric modeling techniques are examined . <edu_end> study shows <edu_end> that the traditional kernel regression , general regression neural network , similarity based modeling and radial basis function network are examples of space kernel analysis with specified space kernel matrices . <edu_end>
the problem <edu_end> of representing and reasoning about two notions of time <edu_end> that are relevant in the context of knowledge bases <edu_end> is addressed . <edu_end> these are called historical time and belief time respectively . <edu_end> historical time denotes the time <edu_end> for which information models reality / belief time <edu_end> denotes the time <edu_end> lor <edu_end> which a belief is held -lrb- by an agent or a knowledge base -rrb- . <edu_end> we formalize an appropriate theory of time <edu_end> using logic as a metalanguage . <edu_end> we then present a metalogic program <edu_end> derived from this theory of time through fold / unfold transformations . <edu_end> the metalogic program enables the temporal reasoning <edu_end> required for knowledge base applications to be carried out efficiently . <edu_end> the metalogic program is directly implementable as a prolog program <edu_end> and hence the need for a more complex theorem prover is obviated . <edu_end> the metalogic program is applicable for such knowledge base applications as legislation and legal reasoning and in the context of multi - agent reasoning <edu_end> where an agent reasons about the beliefs of another agent . <edu_end>

pronunciation variations can be roughly classified into two types : <edu_end> a phone change or a sound change -lsb- 1 -rsb- -lsb- 2 -rsb- . a phone change happens <edu_end> when a canonical phone is produced as a different phone . <edu_end> such a change can be modeled <edu_end> by converting the baseform phone to a surfaceform phone . <edu_end> a sound change happens at a lower , phonetic or subphonetic level within a phone <edu_end> and it can not be modeled well by either the baseform or the surfaceform phone alone . <edu_end> we propose here to refine the acoustic models <edu_end> to cope with sound changes by -lrb- 1 -rrb- sharing the gaussian mixture components of hmm states in the baseform and the surfaceform models ; <edu_end> -lrb- 2 -rrb- adapting the mixture components of the acoustic models towards those of the surfaceform models ; <edu_end> -lrb- 3 -rrb- selectively reconstructing new acoustic models <edu_end> through sharing or adapting . <edu_end> the proposed pronunciation modeling algorithms are generic <edu_end> and can , in principle , be applied to different languages . <edu_end> specifically , pronunciation modeling algorithms were tested in a cantonese speech recognition database . <edu_end> relative word error rate reductions of 5.45 % , 2.53 % , and 3.04 % have been achieved <edu_end> using the three approaches , respectively . <edu_end>

conventional plda scoring in i - vector speaker verification involves the i - vectors of target speakers and claimants only . <edu_end> we have previously demonstrated <edu_end> that better performance can be achieved <edu_end> by incorporating the information of background speakers in the scoring process via speaker - dependent svms . <edu_end> this is achieved <edu_end> by defining a plda score space with dimension equal to the number of training <edu_end> i - vectors for each target speaker . <edu_end> the new protocol in nist 2012 sre permits systems to use the information of other target - speakers -lrb- called known non - targets -rrb- in each verification trial . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we exploit this new protocol <edu_end> to enhance the performance of plda - svm scoring <edu_end> by using the score vectors of both known and unknown non - targets as the impostor class data <edu_end> to train the speaker - dependent svms . <edu_end> because some target speakers have one enrollment utterance only , <edu_end> which results in severe imbalance in the speaker - and impostor - class data for svm training . <edu_end> this paper shows <edu_end> that <edu_end> if the enrollment utterance is sufficiently long , <edu_end> a number of target - speaker i - vectors can be generated by an utterance partitioning and resam - pling technique , <edu_end> resulting in much better scoring svms . <edu_end> results on nist 2012 sre demonstrate the advantages <edu_end> of pooling the known and unknown non - targets <edu_end> for training the svms <edu_end> and that the resam - pling techniques can help the svm training algorithm to find better decision boundaries for those speakers with only a small number of enrollment utterances . <edu_end>
this paper presents a rapid voice adaptation algorithm <edu_end> using gmm - based frequency warping and shift with parameters of a sub - band basis spectrum model -lsb- 1 -rsb- . <edu_end> the sub - band basis spectrum model represents a shape of a spectrum of speech . <edu_end> rapid voice adaptation algorithm is calculated <edu_end> by fitting a sub - band basis to the log - spectrum . <edu_end> since the sub - band basis spectrum model is the frequency domain representation , <edu_end> frequency warping can be directly applied to the sub - band basis spectrum model . a frequency warping function <edu_end> that minimize the distance between source and target sub - band basis spectrum model pairs in each mixture component of a gmm is derived <edu_end> using a dp -lrb- dynamic programming -rrb- algorithm . <edu_end> the proposed rapid voice adaptation algorithm is evaluated in an unit - selection based voice adaptation framework <edu_end> applied to a unit - fusion based text - to - speech synthesizer . <edu_end> the experimental results show <edu_end> that the proposed rapid voice adaptation algorithm is effective for rapid voice adaptation <edu_end> using just one sentence , <edu_end> compared to the conventional gmm.-based linear transformation of mel - cepstra . <edu_end>
this article shows <edu_end> how rational analysis can be used <edu_end> to minimize learning cost for a general class of statistical learning problems . <edu_end> we discuss the factors <edu_end> that influence learning cost <edu_end> and show <edu_end> that the problem of effr - cient learning can be cast as a resource optimization problem . <edu_end> solutions <edu_end> found in this way <edu_end> can be significantly more efficient than the best solutions <edu_end> that do not account for these factors . <edu_end> we introduce a heuristic learning algorithm <edu_end> that approximately solves this optimization problem <edu_end> and document its performance improvements on synthetic and real - world problems . <edu_end> se1191 -rsb- -rrb- of these factors <edu_end> to minimize learning cost . <edu_end> we discuss this in the context of parametric hypothesis selection problems , an abstract class of statistical learning problems <edu_end> where a system must select one of a finite set of hypothesized courses of action , <edu_end> where the quality of each hypothesis is described as a function of some unknown parameters -lrb- e.g. . <edu_end> a heuristic learning algorithm determines and refines estimates of these parameters <edu_end> by '' paying for '' training examples . <edu_end>
the purpose of a voice conversion system is to change the perceived speaker identity of a speech signal . <edu_end> in this paper , <edu_end> we propose a new algorithm <edu_end> based on converting the lpc spectrum <edu_end> and predicting the residual as a function of the target envelope parameters . <edu_end> we conduct listening tests <edu_end> based on speaker discrimination of same / difference pairs <edu_end> to measure the accuracy <edu_end> by which the converted voices match the desired target voices . <edu_end> to establish the level of human performance as a baseline , <edu_end> we first measure the ability of listeners to discriminate between original speech utterances under three conditions : <edu_end> normal , fundamental frequency and duration normalized , and lpc coded . <edu_end> additionally , the spectral parameter conversion function is tested in isolation <edu_end> by listening to source , target , and converted speakers as lpc coded speech . <edu_end> the results show <edu_end> that the speaker identity of speech <edu_end> whose lpc spectrum has been converted <edu_end> can be recognized as the target speaker with the same level of performance <edu_end> as discriminating between lpc coded speech . <edu_end> however , the level of discrimination of converted utterances <edu_end> produced by the voice conversion system <edu_end> is significantly below that of speaker discrimination of natural speech . <edu_end>
training machine learning models sometimes needs to be done on large amounts of data <edu_end> that exceed the capacity of a single machine , <edu_end> motivating recent works on developing algorithms <edu_end> that train in a distributed fashion . <edu_end> this paper proposes an efficient box - constrained quadratic optimization algorithm <edu_end> for distributedly training linear support vector machines -lrb- svms -rrb- with large data . <edu_end> our key technical contribution is an analytical solution to the problem <edu_end> of computing the optimal step size at each iteration , <edu_end> using an efficient analytical solution <edu_end> that requires only o communication cost <edu_end> to ensure fast convergence . <edu_end> with this optimal step size , our analytical solution is superior to other methods <edu_end> by possessing global linear convergence , or , equivalently , o -lrb- log -lrb- 1 / / -rrb- -rrb- iteration complexity for an - accurate solution , for dis - tributedly solving the non - strongly - convex linear svm dual problem . <edu_end> experiments also show <edu_end> that our analytical solution is significantly faster than state - of - the - art distributed linear svm algorithms <edu_end> including dsvm - ave , disdca and tron . <edu_end>
in syntax - based machine translation , <edu_end> rule selection is the task <edu_end> of choosing the correct target side of a translation rule among rules with the same source side . <edu_end> we define a discriminative rule selection model for systems <edu_end> that have syntactic annotation on the target language side -lrb- string - to - tree -rrb- . <edu_end> this is a new and clean way <edu_end> to integrate soft source syntactic constraints into string - to - tree systems as features of the rule selection model . <edu_end> we release our implementation as part of moses . <edu_end>
efficient design of wireless networks <edu_end> requires implementation of cross - layer algorithms <edu_end> that exploit channel state information . <edu_end> capitalizing on convex optimization and stochastic approximation tools , <edu_end> this paper develops a stochastic algorithm <edu_end> that allocates resources at network , link , and physical layers <edu_end> so that a sum - utility of the average end - to - end rates is maximized . <edu_end> focus is placed on wireless networks <edu_end> where interference is strong <edu_end> and nodes transmit orthogonally over a set of parallel channels . <edu_end> convergence of the developed stochastic schemes is characterized , <edu_end> and the average queue delays are obtained in closed form . <edu_end>
reverberation distorts human speech <edu_end> and usually has negative effects on speech intelligibility , especially for hearing - impaired listeners . <edu_end> it also causes performance degradation in automatic speech recognition and speaker identification systems . <edu_end> therefore , the dereverberation problem must be dealt with in daily listening environments . <edu_end> we propose to use deep neural networks <edu_end> to learn a spectral mapping from the reverberant speech to the anechoic speech . <edu_end> the trained deep neural networks produces the estimated spectral representation of the corresponding anechoic speech . <edu_end> we demonstrate <edu_end> that distortion caused by reverberation <edu_end> is substantially attenuated by the deep neural networks <edu_end> whose outputs can be resynthesized to the derever - ebrated speech signal . <edu_end> the proposed deep neural networks is simple , <edu_end> and our systematic evaluation shows promising dereverberation results , <edu_end> which are significantly better than those of related systems . <edu_end>
this paper investigates algorithms <edu_end> to automatically adapt the learning rate of neural networks . <edu_end> starting with stochastic gradient descent , <edu_end> a large variety of learning methods has been proposed for the nn setting . <edu_end> however , these methods are usually sensitive to the initial learning rate <edu_end> which has to be chosen by the exper - imenter . <edu_end> we investigate several features <edu_end> and show <edu_end> how an adaptive controller can adjust the learning rate <edu_end> without prior knowledge of the learning problem at hand . <edu_end>
